intro: Cnemidophacos argillosus, commonly known as the clay-root liverwort, is a type of non-vascular plant belonging to the family Pottiaceae. It is characterized by its small, densely packed leaves that are often covered in a waxy layer, which helps it retain moisture in arid environments. This liverwort thrives in moist, shaded areas, particularly on clay-rich soils, where it forms dense mats. Its reproductive structures, known as capsules, are borne on short stalks and release spores into the air. Due to its ability to survive in harsh conditions, it is often found in rocky or disturbed habitats.
